content.body:
Following up on that â€” what is the expected behavior for a maplike (or setlike)? In my understanding, a maplike should work as a map, so iterating should use live data. 
But then there is [this wpt](https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/b2a38f9f6f/css/css-highlight-api/HighlightRegistry-iteration-with-modifications.html), which (given the commit message) deliberately iterates on a copy of the data. Is there some section in the spec Iâ€™m missing, or is this not defined properly?
content.formatted_body:

But then there is this wpt, which (given the commit message) deliberately iterates on a copy of the data. Is there some section in the spec Iâ€™m missing, or is this not defined properly?

content.body:
The button background color is not changing when toggling between fullscreen and no fullscreen using F11 and Esc. 

Link: https://pastebin.com/KQqMMjUh

I have a random shot-in-the-dark questionâ€¦ not sure if this is the right place to ask it.

Recently HTMX has seen a surge in popularity, and, in particular, I think its users have some interest in standardizing some of its features, especially having HTML have the ability to do same-origin requests for HTML document fragments and swapping/merging them into the current page.

Is WHATWG the right forum to discuss something like this? (If not, is there a better place for that discussion?)
Dan Fabulich: it seems like a good place to discuss. File a spec issue for html
content.formatted_body: Dan Fabulich: it seems like a good place to discuss. File a spec issue for html

content.body: There's probably an issue for client-side includes already, if I understand the suggestion correctly.
not exactly, it's submitting a form that only replaces part of the document
I'm actually a bit stumped on how to write "use cases" for declarative AJAX. (It does so much!)
Dan Fabulich: search the web for "HTMx use cases" and you'll probably find copy-pastable things
content.formatted_body: Dan Fabulich: search the web for "HTMx use cases" and you'll probably find copy-pastable things
